Row.Text: Fëanor was born in Valinor, the only child of Finwë, High King of the Ñoldor, and Finwë's first wife Míriel Therindë. He was renowned as a craftsman, gem-smith, and warrior, the maker of the Silmarils. Learning of his father's death at the hands of Morgoth, Fëanor went back to Tirion, breaking the exile set by the Valar. At Tirion, Fëanor gave an impassioned speech in which he convinced the vast majority of the Ñoldor to follow him to Middle-earth to wrest the Silmarils back from Morgoth and avenge Finwë. At the end of his speech, furious and ever prideful, Fëanor swore the dreadful oath to Eru, calling Manwë and Varda in witness. This oath saw him pledge, on pain of calling upon himself the Everlasting Darkness, to pursue with violence any who would keep or hold a Silmaril from him, no who it was, and no matter what the reason or circumstance.

Maedhros was one of the princes of the Ñoldor, the eldest of the seven Sons of Fëanor and head of the House of Fëanor following the death of his father in Middle-earth. He was extraordinarily renowned for his skill both as a warrior and as a diplomat. For hundreds of years, he led his House against the forces of Morgoth but the Oath that he and his six brothers had sworn to recover the Silmarils constrained him and ultimately led to his death.

Celegorm, was the third son of Fëanor and Nerdanel, most closely associated with another brother, Curufin. Celegorm was a great huntsman, and a friend of the Vala Oromë. From Oromë he learned great skill of birds and beasts, and could understand a number of their languages. He had brought with him from Valinor the great hound Huan, a gift from Oromë.

Maglor was the second son of Fëanor and Nerdanel. He was the greatest poet and minstrel of the Ñoldor and was said to have inherited more of his mother's gentler temperament. As with the other Sons of Fëanor, Maglor was bound by an oath to recover his father's Silmarils, which had been stolen by the Dark Lord Morgoth.

Caranthir was the fourth son of Fëanor and the harshest and the quickest to anger of his seven brothers. Caranthir was bound by an oath to recover his father's Silmarils, which had been stolen by the Dark Lord Morgoth in Aman. Because his realm bordered the great Dwarfish Kingdoms of Nogrod and Belegost in the Blue Mountains (Ered Luin), he became very wealthy probably controlling much of the trade coming through the Dwarf-Road.
Amrod was the youngest son of Fëanor, along with his twin brother Amras. He held the lands of Estolad with his brother.

Fingolfin was the second High King of the Ñoldor in Beleriand. He was the eldest son of Finwë and Indis, younger brother of Findis, older brother of Irimë and Finarfin, and the younger half-brother of Fëanor. He founded the House of Fingolfin, which ruled the Ñoldor in Middle-earth. His wife was Anairë and his children were Fingon, Turgon, Aredhel, and Argon. Fingolfin was said to be the strongest, most steadfast, and most valiant of Finwë's sons.

Finrod was the eldest son of Fingolfin.Fingon marched to Thangorodrim and with the help of Thorondor, Lord of the Eagles, found Maedhros. Maedhros begged Fingon to kill him, but Fingon instead severed Maedhros's hand by the wrist, and brought him back to the Noldorin camp. Maedhros renounced his claim to the High Kingship of the Ñoldor, instead ceding it to House of Fingolfin.

Turgon was the second son of Fingolfin. Turgon was the King of Gondolin and the High King of the Ñoldor. For hundreds of years of the First Age, Turgon remained successfully hidden from the eyes and ears of Morgoth until a betrayal from within caused his downfall. Turgon was instructed by Ulmo to prepare a secret kingdom and was shown the hidden valley of Tumladen in the Encircling Mountains. After 52 years of secret labor, Turgon led his people into Gondolin, where he ruled for over 500 years, largely ignoring the events of the Wars of Beleriand.

Finrod was the eldest son of Finarfin and Eärwen, and the brother of Galadriel, Angrod and Aegnor. Finrod was one of the noblest elves of the House of Finarfin and a friend of Men. His nobility and death saving Beren and his opposition to the Oath of Fëanor allowed for his return to life in Valinor, making him the first Elf to be reincarnated in Undying Lands before the end of First Age.

Orodreth was the son of Finarfin's son Angrod. He once held the isle of Minas Tirith in the vale of Sirion until Sauron overran the isle and turned it into Tol-in-Gaurhoth. Orodreth then fled south to Nargothrond.

Angrod was the second son of Finarfin and lord of the Ñoldor of Dorthonion. He was the father of Orodreth and subsequently grandfather of the famed Gil-galad. Together with Aegnor he held the northern slopes of the highlands of Dorthonion against Morgoth. They were both killed in the Dagor Bragollach.

Melkor, later known Morgoth,was the first Dark Lord, and the primordial source of evil in Eä. Originally the most powerful of the Ainur created by Eru Iluvatar, Melkor rebelled against his creator out of pride. After committing many evils in the First Age, such as the theft of the Silmarils, which resulted in his name Morgoth, and the destruction of the Two Lamps and the Two Trees of Valinor, Morgoth was defeated by the Host of Valinor in the War of Wrath and cast out of Arda into the Void, where he now waits.

Thingol was the founder and first King of the northern Elven Kingdom of Doriath and was respected by all the Sindar of the Beleriand, who considered him to be the High King of the Sindar and the Lord of Beleriand. He and Melian, a Maia, become king and queen of the Teleri who stay in Beleriand, who then become known as the Sindar.

Dior Eluchîl, was a Half-Elf son of the renowned Man Beren and the legendary Elven-princess Lúthien of Doriath. He thereafter became the King of Doriath as he was heir to the throne of King Thingol of Doriath and also became the High King of the Sindar.

Denethor led many of his people over the Blue Mountains to Beleriand. They settled in Ossiriand, renaming it Lindon, in the east of Beleriand, and Denethor became their king. Morgoth loosed an army on Beleriand beginning the First Battle. The lightly-armed Laiquendi were driven back to the great hill of Amon Ereb, where Denethor was slain. The Laiquendi became a reclusive people, seldom taking up arms, and never again naming a king.
Húrin Thalion was a hero and the greatest warrior of Men during the First Age. Húrin was the Lord of Dor-lómin and ruled over the Hadorian fief of Dor-lómin in Hithlum.

King Durin I was the oldest of the Seven Fathers of the Dwarves, first created by Aulë the Vala. Durin was set to sleep alone beneath Mount Gundabad in Middle-earth until the Elves awoke. Upon his awakening at Mount Gundabad in the Years of the Trees, he traveled until he came upon the Mirrormere, the lake that the Dwarves call Kheled-zâram. He created there a great city within the Misty Mountains. This was Khazad-dûm, known by Elves as Moria.

Azaghâl was the King of the Broadbeam Dwarves, one of the seven Dwarf clans, and was lord of the kingdom of Belegost in the Blue Mountains during the First Age. He and his Dwarves fighted alone in the Battle of Nirnaeth Arnoediad against the Dragon Glaurung, the Father of Dragons.

Naugladur was the Lord of Nogrod; the King of the Wicked dwarves of Nogrod. More prone to evil to gain their ends, and more exclusively impelled by greed; that Doriath should be laid waste by mercenary Orcs under Dwarvish paymasters.

Finarfin was the youngest child and third son of Finwë, High-King of the Noldor in Aman, with his second wife Indis of the Vanyar. He departed with his brothers Fëanor and Fingolfin for Middle-earth, but turned back when Mandos pronounced the Doom of the Ñoldor. Finarfin and his people were pardoned by the Valar, and then he became King of the residual Ñoldor in Aman and presumably still rules from Tirion. During the War of Wrath, Finarfin led a large battalion of the Valar, comprised of Ñoldorin, Vanyarin, and Telerin Elves.

Ingwë was a Vanyar Elf, the King of the Vanyar and the High King of the Elves. Ingwë became the first of the Vanyar to travel to Valinor with Oromë. Loving its beauty and bliss, he returned to his people and urged them to undertake a journey to Aman. He and his kin were fascinated with the Valar.

Olwë was an Elf of the Teleri of Aman. When he and his kin reached Aman, they chose to remain there in both Tol Eressëa and Alqualondë apart from the rest of the Elves of Aman. He became both Lord of Alqualondë and King of the Teleri. The cruel slaying at the havens continued to haunt Olwë and his people for many years to come. Towards the end of the First Age when the Valar were preparing for the final assault on Morgoth, the Teleri of Olwë agreed only to sail the ships for very few of them were willing to go to war.
Other civilizations' [ICON_TRADEROUTE] Trade Routes to you provide +2 Faith [ICON_FAITH].
Holy Sites gains +1 [ICON_Faith] Faith for Forest adjacency.
-50% war weariness from combat in your territory.
Light cavalry units receive +4 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength.
Commercial Hubs gains 1 [ICON_Gold] Gold if they are next to a Mountain.
All districts gain +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold for being adjacent to the Coast.
Industrial Zones gains +1 [ICON_Production] Production for Forest adjacency.
All districts gain +1 [ICON_Faith] Faith for being adjacent to the Coast.
All districts gain +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture for being adjacent to the Coast.
City State of Havens of Sirion
Combat victories provide [ICON_Faith] Faith equal to 20% of the [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength of the defeated unit.
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when fighting on Hills
Your [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Routes to any city-state provide +2 [ICON_Culture] Culture and +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold for every specialty district in the origin city.
City State of Beor of Ladros
Combat victories provide [ICON_Gold] Gold equal to 25% of the [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength of the defeated unit.
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +3 [ICON_Faith] Faith and +1 [ICON_Science] Science to adjacent tiles.

“Varda looked down from Taniquetil, and beheld the Shadow soaring up in sudden towers of gloom; Valmar had foundered in a deep sea of night. Soon the Holy Mountain stood alone, a last island in a world that was drowned.”[NEWLINE]– The Silmarillion, Ch 8: Of The Darkening of Valinor
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold and +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture to adjacent tiles.

“Mount Taras, westernmost of all the towers of that land, whose head a mariner would first descry across the miles of the sea, as he drew near to the mortal shores. Beneath its long slopes in bygone days Turgon had dwelt in the halls of Vinyamar, eldest of all the works of stone that the Noldor built in the lands of their exile. ”[NEWLINE]– Unfinished Tales, Ch 1: Of Tuor and His Coming to Gondolin
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold and +1 [ICON_Faith] Faith to adjacent tiles.

“Mount Taras, westernmost of all the towers of that land, whose head a mariner would first descry across the miles of the sea, as he drew near to the mortal shores. Beneath its long slopes in bygone days Turgon had dwelt in the halls of Vinyamar, eldest of all the works of stone that the Noldor built in the lands of their exile. ”[NEWLINE]– Unfinished Tales, Ch 1: Of Tuor and His Coming to Gondolin
Three tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +2 [ICON_Gold] Gold and +1 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.

Mount Dolmed loomed over the only known pass from Eriador into Beleriand. It was here that according to the Dwarves two of the Fathers of the Dwarves, the founders of the Broadbeams and the Firebeards, awoke. Their descendants later established the Dwarven cities of Nogrod and Belegost.

Two tile natural wonder. It appears as a Lake and provides +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith, +1 [ICON_Science] Science and +1 [ICON_Food] Food, and Fresh Water. Units heal completely if they heal for one turn adjacent to the Eithel Ivrin.

“They passed westward over Sirion and came at length to Eithel Ivrin, the springs whence Narog rose beneath the Mountains of Shadow. There Gwindor spoke to Túrin, saying: 'Awake, Túrin son of Húrin Thalion! On Ivrin's lake is endless laughter. She is fed from crystal fountains unfailing, and guarded from defilement by Ulmo, Lord of Waters, who wrought her beauty in ancient days.' Then Túrin knelt and drank from that water; and suddenly he cast himself down, and his tears were unloosed at last, and he was healed of his madness.”[NEWLINE]– The Silmarillion, Ch 21: Of Túrin Turambar
Two tile natural wonder. It appears as a Lake and provides +2 [ICON_Faith] Faith, +2 [ICON_Culture] Culture and +1 [ICON_Food] Food, and Fresh Water.

“The waters of Tarn Aeluin were held in reverence, for they were clear and blue by day and by night were a mirror for the stars; and it was said that Melian herself had hallowed that water in the days of old.”[NEWLINE]– The Silmarillion, Ch 19: Of Beren and Lúthien
One tile impassable natural wonder. It appears as a Mountain and provides +1 [ICON_Gold] Gold and +1 [ICON_Production] Production to adjacent tiles.

“Even above the stony heath at its base its crown was reared up a thousand feet and more. Upon the eastern side a broken land climbed slowly up to the high ridges among knots of birch and rowan, and ancient thorn-trees rooted in rock. About the lower slopes of Amon Rûdh there grew thickets of aeglos; but its steep grey head was bare, save for the red seregon that mantled the stone.”[NEWLINE]– Unfinished Tales, Ch 2: Narn I Hîn Húrin: Of Mîm the Dwarf
